body: LEAD: A man with a police record and possible ties to organized crime was shot and killed on a Brooklyn street yesterday afternoon by two gunmen who fled in a car. The police said the killing was similar to a series of gangland-style murders in Brooklyn in recent months. A man with a police record and possible ties to organized crime was shot and
title: Another Man Is Slain In a Mob-Style Killing

body: LEAD: A PLAQUE at the end of the Canarsie Pier is inscribed with the words of Henry Meyer, a 19th-century developer: ''Jamaica Bay awaits the touch of the magic wand that will transform it into the Wonder Harbor of the World.'' title: Ripples of Change Flutter on Jamaica Bay

body: LEAD: Huge concrete slabs rest amid the tall reeds, eerie reminders of a long-ago plan to transform the south Brooklyn waterfront into a great harbor. Seagulls perch on partially submerged wood pilings where a 17th-century grist mill once stood. And, as children play on the ballfields north of Avenue U, an occasional speedboat pulls into the
title: A Wilderness Ramble in Brooklyn

body: LEAD: Mayor Koch warned yesterday that people who abandon cars in New York City would be hunted down and fined $500. title: KOCH WARNS ABANDONED-CAR OWNERS OF $500 FINE

body: LEAD: WHERE are the wild things? WHERE are the wild things? They're in New York City again. In the last few years, nature lovers and park officials have noted a resurgence of wild animals - from swans and hawks to turtles and woodchucks - the likes of which have not been seen here for many decades. Although there are no precise statistics to
title: LONG-ABSENT WILDLIFE RETURNS TO CITY PARKS

body: LEAD: TIME was, when the musical season ended in New York, concert halls went dark and listeners had to wait till midsummer for the gates of Tanglewood and other outdoor festivals to open up for business. Nowadays, the schedule of concerts is a nearly unbroken series of events. Air-conditioning of halls, a growing population of concertgoers who
title: SUMMER BEAT: SEPARATE BUT UNIVERSAL SOUNDS; THE CLASSICS, FROM 'BOHEME' TO BARBER

body: LEAD: THE Metropolitan Opera began its 21st season of parks concerts yesterday evening under what could hardly have been better circumstances. There were clear blue skies and warm temperatures as a pleasant breeze blew across the Great Lawn of Central Park, where the company presented Puccini's ''Tosca'' before a crowd of picknickers, opera fans
title: OPERA: A 'TOSCA' IN THE PARK

body: LEAD: For Sherrill Milnes, the big problem is bugs, he said. After all, it is tough enough to sing an aria in front of 200,000 people without worrying about a mosquito sizing up your tongue. There are also car horns to contend with, as well as airplanes, sweltering temperatures and picnickers who've perhaps drunk a little too much sparkling wine.
title: TUNING UP FOR 'TOSCA' IN THE PARK

body: LEAD: Because of a strict new law regulating the disposal of asbestos, more and more landlords in New York City are removing the hazardous material secretly and dumping it illegally, according to sanitation officials. title: ILLEGAL ASBESTOS DUMPING SOARS UNDER NEW LAW

body: LEAD: The Metropolitan Opera's 21st season of free concerts will open with a production of Puccini's ''Tosca'' at Central Park's Great Lawn on June 16, featuring Placido Domingo, Marilyn Zschau and Sherrill Milnes. title: Operas in the Park To Open With 'Tosca'

body: LEAD: ''I could've been a contender,'' Asa Hoffmann said. ''I could've been a grandmaster.'' Instead, Mr. Hoffmann is a hustler, the Fast Eddie Felson of the knight and rook set. body: LEAD: AS winter moves into its final month this weekend, New Yorkers may already be dreaming of spring. Nevertheless, many cold-weather pleasures still await the intrepid outdoor explorer. title: A GUIDE TO SLIDING, GLIDING AND RIDING ON A WINTRY DAY
